case_name: Atyam Veerraju v. Nuli Subba Rao and Pechetti Venkanna

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATe JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated March 24, 1960 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 198 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 24, 1960 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 198 of 1957.

facts.text: Suit instituted by Atyam Veerraju as trustee of Sri Janardhana Swami Varu against Nuli Subba Rao and Pechetti Venkanna for recovery of possession of lands.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit instituted by Atyam Veerraju as trustee of Sri Janardhana Swami Varu of Penugonda, a Hindu deity, against Nuli Subba Rao and Pechetti Venkanna for recovery of possession of agricultural Inam lands,

facts.text: Suit lands are agricultural Inam lands R.S. No. 153/3 (2 acres 38 cents) and R.S. No. 167 (4 acres 36 cents), totaling 6 acres 74 cents in Cherukuvada village, West Godavari District, Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: R.S. No. 153/3, 2 acres 38 cents and R.S. No. 167, 4 acres 36 cents, totaling 6 acres 74 cents in Cherukuvada village, West Godavari District, Andhra Pradesh. The case made in the plaint is as follows The suit lands belong to Sri Janardhana Swami Varu.

facts.text: Suit lands belong to Sri Janardhana Swami Varu.

anchor.surface_text: The suit lands belong to Sri Janardhana Swami Varu.

facts.text: In 1851, Ponnuri Anandu, Archaka and de facto trustee, arranged with Nuli Peda Narasimhulu (great grandfather of first defendant) to supply one-fourth seer of gingili oil daily to temple and enjoy income of lands.

anchor.surface_text: In 1851, one Ponnuri Anandu, the then Archaka and de facto trustee of the temple, arranged with Nuli Peda Narasimhulu, the great grandfather of the first defendant, that the latter would supply one- Fourth seer of gingili oil every day to the temple and instead of receiving the price of the oil would enjoy the income of the lands.

facts.text: Arrangement of 1851 reduced into writing.

anchor.surface_text: The arrangement was reduced into writing.

facts.text: First defendant and predecessors in possession under 1851 arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant and his predecessors have been in possession of the lands under this arrangement.

facts.text: Arrangement terminated by notices dated December 6, 1948 and August 31, 1949 issued by plaintiff's advocate to first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The arrangement was put an end to by numberices dated December 6, 1948 and August 31, 1949 issued by the plaintiffs advocate to the first defendant.

facts.text: Second defendant is lessee of suit lands from first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The second defendant is a lessee of the suit lands under the first defendant.

facts.text: First defendant died pending suit; third and fourth defendants substituted as legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the suit, the first defendant died, and his legal representatives, the third and fourth defendants, were substituted in his place.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Eluru dismissed suit, finding lands belong to deity, 1851 permanent lease, adverse possession by defendants.

facts.text: High Court confirmed decree dismissing suit, agreeing on adverse possession.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was companyfirmed by the High Court on appeal. Without expressing any opinion on the first two questions, the High Court agreed with the finding of the trial Court on the question of adverse possession.

facts.text: Plaintiff and two others appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff and two other persons number appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Inam Fair Register shows deity as inamdar since 1795, sold to deity in 1851 for Rs. 120.

facts.text: Inam Commissioner order dated October 27, 1859 confirmed deity's title as inamdar, issued title deed No. 469.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the Inam Commissioner dated October 27, 1859, the title of the deity as inamdar of the suit lands was companyfirmed and title deed No. 469 was issued to the deity.

facts.text: Hindu Religious Endowments Board framed scheme dated October 26, 1931 showing suit lands as deity's property in possession of Nuli Subba Rao; confirmed by District Judge decree December 4, 1937.

facts.text: Defendants' documents show possession and enjoyment by Peda Narasimhulu and successors since 1851, including mortgages and leases.

Exhibit B-1 dated October 19, 1895 shows a mortgage...

holdings.text: The contention that Peda Narasimhulu and his successors-in-interest acquired title to the suit lands by prescription and the suit is barred by limitation is therefore, rejected

anchor.surface_text: The contention that Peda Narasimhulu and his successors-in-interest acquired title to the suit lands by prescription and the suit is barred by limitation is therefore, rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no adverse possession during tenancy 1851-1949; limitation not run from 1851 or 1929; Art.139 applies from 1949.

holdings.text: the plaintiff is, therefore, entitled to recover the suit lands

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the notice terminating the tenancy is not disputed. The plaintiff is, therefore, entitled to recover the suit lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenancy terminated by valid notice; no defence of title or limitation; trustees represent deity.
